attributes.title: Distribution of Secondhand Computers in Ghana

attributes.description: A typical small Internet cafe with about 10 screens and equipped with secondhand computers.
attributes.title: FocusNet Internet Cafe

attributes.description:
The General Services Administration (GSA) is an independent agency of the United States government, established in 1949 to help manage and support the basic functioning of federal agencies. (source wikipedia)

The GSA is partly tasked with "Directing and developing regulations to ensure effective utilization of, investment in, and disposal of federal real property assets."

It is probable that exporters shipping computers to sell in Ghana are using GSA auction services such as: http://gsaauctions.gov/gsaauctions/aucitsrh/ to acquire these goods.

At an Internet Cafe named 'Sky Harbour' in a suburb of Accra, I found a CRT monitor with a property tag that identified it as "property of the US Environmental Protection Agency."

attributes.description: Property Tags are often left on the secondhand computers that are imported into Ghana. At a secondhand computer shop in Accra (House Party Computers) I found property tags that identified the New York Public Library as the source for a set of Dell Optiplex GX280 desktop computers.

attributes.title: Obsolete Computers

attributes.description:
Secondhand computers are imported from countries that (not incidentally) host large Ghanaian diasporic populations.  Many secondhand computer businesses are run by transnational families travelling between home and host countries.

A recent UN report titled 'Where are WEEE in Africa?' found that 30% of the used computers imported into Ghana were non-working on arrival. Half of those are refurbished and repaired. This figure is much lower than some early estimates. Working computers are sold and used in homes, offices, and Internet cafes throughout Accra.

The attached table specifies from 2004 to 2009 how many computers were imported and from which countries.  The data was provided by the gov of Ghana.
attributes.title: Tema Harbour
Agbogbloshie Dump Site
attributes.description: The infamous images of Ghana's e-waste dump site at Agbogbloshie (as seen in the NY Times, National Geographic, and a Frontline documentary) were captured here. However, the whole rest of the process of import, refurbishment, resale, and reuse that eventually leads to scrap metal extracting and dumping is often obscured.

attributes.title: Agbogbloshie Scrap Metal Yard
attributes.description: Iron, aluminum, and (most valuably) copper is extracted from computers, CRT monitors, and other electronics (including refrigerators, televisions, etc) at the Agbogbloshie scrap metal yard.

attributes.title: House Party Computers, Newtown
attributes.description: House Party Computers is a chain of stores that sells secondhand computers in Ghana. One employee estimated that the company imports 30-40 containers (40 ft) filled with computers each year, mostly from the USA.

attributes.title: Sky Harbour Internet Cafe
attributes.description: A typical, small neighborhood Internet cafe equipped with imported secondhand computers.  When I last visited in June 2010, I discovered a working computer monitor with a property tag that identified it as "property of the US Environmental Protection Agency."  The desktop wallpaper had been set to an image of President Obama.

attributes.title: Secondhand Computer Shops
attributes.description:
This particular area on the outskirts of Accra known as 'Lapaz' has many smaller shops selling secondhand computers. Computer importers vary in terms of their business connections and savvy. Well-run shops have many identical machines (which makes repair and refurbishment easier). When a new shipment arrives, technicians work to get as many of the computers up and running as possible in order to recoup the cost of the computers themselves, VAT tax, and expense of shipping.

Many computers are sold alongside other household electronics including stereo systems, irons, televisions, and microwaves.

attributes.title: Valco and Steel Works
attributes.description: These plants located in the Tema industrial area buy scrap metal (iron, aluminum) and recycle it

attributes.title: Scrap Metal Collection Point
attributes.description: The photos associated with this point are not from this specific location but show the kind of roadside scrap metal collection points that feed (ultimately) to the central Agbogbloshie scrap metal yard.  Men pulling these distinctive wooden carts loaded with scrap metal are a common sight on the roads throughout Accra.
